This serving info is placed under "resource_request" because we need to make sure it won't be filtered according to "fields" parameter in _make_port_dict: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ba77ec3c1921780f5ac08be7d8ce784051a7db89/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_common.py#L260 - before bulk extender even get called: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ba77ec3c1921780f5ac08be7d8ce784051a7db89/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L1566

  resource_request = port_res.pop('resource_request', None)
  port_res['resource_request'] = None
  ...

I had this originally but in review Rodolfo said he wanted a structured API. Dmitri made a similar comment in the past. I agree there is a trade-off here and it does add to the maintenance burden.
neither comment nor name of the struct makes explain what this executor does.
I added a few lines here to explain more about the executor
image
Done
this shouldn't be here
Can you clarify the issue with this line?
camel case

This exposes a conflict between requirements I have received:
1. Rodolfo asked for granular airship interface for image-builder ansible parameters so we can manage overrides with kustomize more easily without resorting to Regex replacements.
2. Ansible naming conventions are in conflict with airship naming conventions. Ansible builtins use lower-case convention with underscore separators, and also do not permit use of dashes.
3. Users I spoke to asked for the ability to copy-paste unaltered ansible overrides developed for stand-alone image-builder into airshipctl manifests. Meaning that it would contain ansible-style variable names.
Do you know if there is a way we can satisfy these requirements without breaking airshipctl naming standards?
use camel case
ditto
ditto, dont use caps

Some of these like the Grub parameters we do have the ability to change because they come from image-builder and are not an immutable ansible built-in. So these parameters we can update in image-builder depending on the outcome of the requirements conflict mentioned previously.
ditto
please dont use underscore anywhere in yaml
I dont understand this, sorry.
The idea with this struct was to reference ansible playbook overrides, with one object for each playbook. I have proposed an alternate naming in the next comment which may add clarity.

I dont understand what this structure is and how it is going to be used as configuration for executor.
Is it Target Image Configuration? Why is it Target, are these images can only be used for target nodes can they be used for workload clusters?

Correct. I have struggled with the correct terminology. I was trying to refer to non-ephemeral base images, which is the intended meaning of Target here. It is meant to be the QCOW2 images where k8s services run for control-plane and worker nodes.
Let me know if you like "TargetBaseImageConfig" as an alternative name, which we could use here instead.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_redhat_enf.message:
I would recommend doing this to ensure precedence:

(tripleo_redhat_enforce | default(true)) | bool
can we really have another precedence here than left to right, given that those are jinja filter ?

I guess it is a matter of safety...but if you have already defined tripleo_redhat_enforce in defaults/main.yaml with a value. Should't that be already the default? this seems a little bit redundant..however I won't block it.

Looking further into precedence issue in jinja filter, this seems to be a problem when you mix it up with math operator:

  foo * 3 | int

should be

  ( foo * 3 ) | int

to have the int filter applied to the result of the foo * 3.

Here, the non precedence version is safe and adding parenthesis would clutter the code with no real gain on safety.

That being said, the comment by @Jose is very pertinent. The variable is set in defaults/main.yml in any case so it will never be empty. In the sake of clarity I'll remove the default altogether as it's not needed.

I add the "default" initially because I remove it from the redhat.yml file, but even downstream the "default true" will not be taken into account because "defaults/main.yml" set it to false.

I have thus an issue if that variable is not set downstream, which is likely if people miss the note about adding it to their plan.

Back to drawing board then ?

refstack/db/migrations/alembic/utils.py.message:
Hi Martin, where is this failing?

I can't see where the return types are changing with python versions just by looking at the libraries and methods used here. I wonder if hardening this a bit like:

 current_name = (current_name.decode() if isinstance(current_name, bytes)
                 else current_name)

would be better?

we don't have a test for that, you need to try it manually ... I was trying to deploy refstack server on my own machine following this doc
https://opendev.org/osf/refstack/src/branch/master/doc/source/refstack.rst
which is btw outdated - it's for py2, not py3, that's another reason I was following the doc - I'm trying to update it.
When you get to the Database sync part, it will be failing at this command:
$ refstack-manage --config-file /path/to/refstack.conf version
^^ that's when that part of the code is executed

that condition you wrote would solve the problem too (I've seen such an example in [1]) , although does it make sense to put it here? this code shouldn't be ever executed by py2, this db migration is different from [1] - I can imagine (I'm not a web developer) that the response content might be in bytes or doesn't. But in the case of db migration code, I don't see such a variability.

[1] https://opendev.org/osf/refstack/src/branch/master/refstack/api/utils.py#L324

I see! I was concerned that the prior output was somehow bytes, and the return types may have changed in a newer version of alembic/sqlalchemy; However, it looks like in python2, we were getting a unicode string, and that's no longer the case with python3 - all strings are the same. There's some language in the alembic docs that highlights a similar issue, and that gives us a hint: https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/cookbook.html#support-non-ascii-migration-scripts-messages-under-python-2
Goutham, why do you want to keep decoding step? My understanding that it works without these lines for py3. Are you anticipating that for some future version we will need to do some decoding?

tox.ini.message: I was thinking about this re: oslo.config >= 8.4.0. Why wouldn't we want to put the requirement in here?

pip does technical allow this, but the lower-constraints job won't because the lower bound specified in 'lower-constraints.txt' won't match the minimum in 'doc/requirements.txt'. More importantly, who would this actually help? It won't help tox users, since pip will always try to use the latest version of a dependency allowed by upper-constraints anyway (run 'tox -e docs' now - oslo.config 8.4.0, i.e. the latest version, will be installed). It won't help packagers either, since there's generally a separate '-doc' package in addition to the main package, and those would need to use the new oslo.config version for both, use two different oslo.config versions for the different packages (can you even do that in e.g. an RPM-based system?), or use the older oslo.config version for both and build docs serially. I seriously expect they'll do the latter since that is obviously what they've been doing all along.

I can just bump the version in requirement.txt if you'd like, but I do think what I've proposed will work graaaand
Thanks. I was missing that it wouldn't work because of lower-constraints. I was just thinking why wouldn't we put the requirement in doc/requirements.txt if there is a requirement? I understand now.

pkg/phase/client.go.message: do we want a single timeout override for all phases, or should it be possible to specify for each phase individually?

This would require enhancement of phase data structure in our document model i.e. each phase document may contain timeout, dryrun and progress keys with some sane default values which can be:
1. overridden by 'airshipctl phase run'
2. globally overridden by 'airshipctl plan run'

This will dramatically increase this CR so I'd move override logic and phase type extension to a separate CR

this looks like we are running phase groups in parallel with each other. Don't we want to run phase groups in succession, and only phases within a given phase group in parallel? Otherwise I don't see how we can have phase dependency ordering and parallel phase execution at the same time.
Removed parallel execution according to our design call discussion

Here are a couple API examples with the same structure I mentioned where the outer list is executed in serial, and the inner list in parallel:

https://github.com/argoproj/argo/blob/master/examples/README.md#steps
https://airshipit.readthedocs.io/projects/armada/en/latest/operations/documents/v1/document-authoring.html

As mentioned before I don't think it can work the other way as phases would need to be in the same group to order them, but nothing in the same group can run in parallel.
We have a concept of multiple phase plans so if we need to create fully parallel plan we can define it. I'll create a topic for design call

This is implemented according to what we have discussed on design call and documented on comments to PhasePlan structure [0]. Dependency ordering can be done within single group and groups must be totally independent. We can try to implement the opposite logic (i.e groups executed sequentially and tasks within groups are parallel) but eventually we end up with different issue: 10, 20 or even 30 groups with one task inside.

The only way to solve this is to introduce DAG which will dramatically increase code complexity and what is more important will decrease user experience for document model developer (he or she would have to define graph in yaml file)

We can discuss this one more time on Design Call though.

[0] https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/blob/master/pkg/api/v1alpha1/phaseplan_types.go#L30-L31

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I went down a long rabbit hole wanting to make it so we could somehow pass both frags along in the one pass.
I started modifying the protocol to add a `:MISSING_CHECK: EXTRA` where you could pass other files, to make it upgradable down the track.. but the further I got the more hacking up of diskfile I needed and changes to how we handle yeild_hashes.. so too much core changes and started getting messy, esp when we want to move to a tsync.

Long story short, we are enabling passing no-durable frags, so the right thing to do is when it's enabled is to provide lastest ts_data. So I'm now ok with having to pass the non durable in the first and the older durable in a second pass 😊

yeah, I also toyed with being able to send multiple timestamps per object per cycle (although I didn't think of a whole new handshake!) but decided to live with the compromise of one ts per cycle.

There's a trade-off: it's an uncommon case to have a stranded durable (we hope!) vs a lot of work to sync it in same cycle as the durable.
yeah yeah, more tests
this addresses the upgrade path; i'm curious what the fallback path looks like

i didn't see a property for this in diskfile.py - i'm assuming this is the canonical way to spell this?

I wondered about adding a property, and I am torn.

Diskfile has become a complex beast. On the one hand it represents a fragment+metadata at a particular timestamp/frag_index. On the other hand it offers the wider view of everything that is on disk for an object (since we needed to parse all that to construct the Diskfile). So it can be confusing as to whether a Diskfile method is on the chosen_frag, or on the whole e.g. is_durable() - meaning the chosen_frag, or meaning there is durable data on disk?

Turns out this equality is tested only here and a couple of times in tests.

No.  The patch orch thread does not follow the same design as the newer upgrade,  firmware or upcoming kube orch threads. The way this code is written allows patch orch thread to be moved toward the newer design, but doing that now adds risk and is outside the scope of this activity.

For AIO-SX, we can continue to do the health check, to avoid changing existing behaviour. For other configs, we should not be doing a health check IF the upgrade was already started. There could be various alarms in this case. The VIM will know better which alarms are acceptable when the strategy is built and fail if necessary - see SwUpgradeStrategy.build and SwUpgradeStrategy.IGNORE_ALARMS. I believe we may need to add alarms to that list in the future to recover from other error cases automatically and I don't want to duplicate that list here.

the health check is pre-existing code.  I dont see how we can omit it (there must have been a reason why it was originally added).

the enhancement here is to allow the 'system upgrade in progress' alarm to not break a 'resume/recovery' in a duplex environment.  and if the alarm does cause it to fail, we generally have to add explicit additional pre-check steps for those on a case by case basis. Presently this allow the orch to resume and complete.

@Sean, I reconsidered about the periodic check. in the periodic check, if mdev does not exsit, cyborg re-create it and update the arq to "BOUND" state. From nova's perspective, when nova resumes guest on host restart, it will get_arq. if at that time the state is not "BOUND", nova needs to wait. but what should nova do about the wait? should it come back later or wait for notification and resumes the instance? Sounds like it will increase the burden in nova side. 

So, I was thinking another possible solution: Cyborg does the check only when a get_arq request comes instead of checking it periodically. e.g. when nova resumes guest on host start, nova calls cyborg's get_arq to get mdev UUID. on cyborg API side, when it receives this get_arq(if attach_type=MDEV) request, it checks if mdev exists, if yes then return UUID directly, if not then create the mdev and return its UUID.

Before discussing about how to segregate within cyborg and nova mdevs, I'd prefer we discuss about the big picture.

I'd prefer solution 3 honestly and the workflow I could see would be :

- Cyborg precreates the mediated devices on computes by calling cyborg-agent directly, after the operator defined the mdev types for each GPU
- Cyborg reports the VGPU inventories accordingly once those mdevs are created
- When a new instance comes by, Nova asks Cyborg whether it can allocate a mdev, and then Cyborg provides an existing mdev uuid
- at spawn() time, nova uses the existing binding methods we have for attaching the mdev uuid to the guest definition.

Et voila, maximum reuse with minimum overlap.
This would leave Cyborg managing the fleet of mdevs exactly like those were SR-IOV VFs, and Cyborg could decide to persist mdev information on computes since those aren't persisted (something which nova doesn't do atm). In the case of a compute reboot, cyborg-agent could recreate the mdevs without involving nova at all, which is the best IMHO.

This reboot case makes me wonder about ordering. Assume we have a VM on the host using a cyborg managed mdev, so the mdev is referred in the VM's domain xml. Then the hypervisor reboot happens so the mdev is gone. The nova-compute and the cyborg-agent restarts along with the hypervisor reboot. How could we make sure that the nova-compute does not come up earlier than the cyborg-agent? Will the nova-compute delays startup until cyborg-agent is started up and re-created the mdevs? If not then resume_guests_state_on_host_boot=True will cause or VM to go into ERROR state. 

In the SRIOV case the solution (I know of) for the disappearing VF problem is to configure the _hypervisor_ to re-create the VFs at PF driver loading. And nova assumes that such driver loading happens early in the hypervisor boot process so when nova-compute starts up the VFs already exists and therefore the VMs can be started up.

From cyborg's perspective, it is a problem of choosing "creating as necessary" or "create all and allocate as necessary". might need to figure out more about the details. I will come back later and update.
However, IMO, cyborg-agent can recreate the mdev without involving nova in either way.

Do I understand correctly that the  solution of host reboot is that nova-compute will call cyborg during the hard_reboot of the VM (triggered by resume_guests_state_on_host_boot=True config) and nova waits until cyborg can respond with the re-created mdev. So if there are VMs on a host using cyborg managed mdevs, and if resume_guests_state_on_host_boot=True then the nova-compute startup sequence will be synchronized with the cyborg startup sequence.

@Balazs I was thinking this as a possible solution before, but this might need to modify init_host when host starts, which is not a general solution. So I think we can just follow how we process so far, if it is an unexpected host reboot, the VM STATUS will be shut down after host reboot, users need to handle it on their own. What would be your suggestions?
IMHO, it's not necessary to synchronize. if the cyborg service start late, we cannot start vm, just like accelerator process so far.

This is interesting. I think if we want to detect the conflict then the detection would be needed on both sides. I.e.:

* If nova sees a PCI device in the whitelist that has an RP already in placement with OWNER_CYBORG then nova-compute can simply fail to start

* if cyborg wants to create a RP for a PCI device but such RP already exists in placement with an OWNER_NOVA trait, then cyborg should fail.

However the second check cannot be implemented today as nova does not report PCI devices in placement today. The PCI tracker is internal and in memory in nova-compute service.

Assuming that in the future nova will store PCI inventory in placement, we need to make sure that both Nova and Cyborg will use the same RP name for the same PCI device. So that placement can reject the second RP creation for the same device. Even after the agreed naming schema we can have race condition between Nova and Cyborg trying to create the RP and then adding the OWNER_ trait to the RP, as these are two separate operations in placement. E.g. There could be a case when the device RP exists but no OWNER_ trait is added yet to it.
Agree, we should make sure Cyborg and Nova use the same RP name for the same PCI device, so the placement will reject the second RP creation, then both sides can aware this.

pkg/util/tableprinter.go.message:
instead of an untyped API and using reflection, what about just having two strongly typed APIs e.g.

NewResourceTable(object []Printable, statusFunc PrintStatusFunction) *ResourceTable
NewSingleResourceTable(object Printable, statusFunc PrintStatusFunction) *ResourceTable

Although creating a slice literal with a single item may be easy enough anyway `NewResourceTable([]Printable{object}, statusFunc).

The idea behind this function is to create table printer based on list of K8s like objects which are essentially implement runtime,Object and meta.Object interfaces(e.g Pod) unfortunately there is no type conversion for slices i.e. []*corev1.Pod can not be converted to []Printable even though *corev1.Pod implements Printable interface (more over even interface{} can not be converted to []interface{}). So if we want this to be convenient for the user we'd need to implement this reflect magic

if we are adding the type alias (PrintResourceStatus) would it make sense to use it here and below so that the type is defined in one place, and any changes made to the type can than automatically be distributed to the usage sites? It may also improve readability.

It looks like you are making several corrections to the API document - I would recommend that you create a single LP - maybe titled "Correct errors in api-ref-sysinv-v1-config.rst document" and use the same LP for the related reviews. You can use a Partial-Bug tag in each commit and then close the LP manually when you are done all your commits.
